user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileOpen_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_FileOpen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *local_path, int32 flags, int32 access_mode)
{
    int                             os_perm;
    int                             os_mode;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Check for a valid access mode
    ** For creating a file, OS_READ_ONLY does not make sense
    */
    switch (access_mode)
    {
        case OS_WRITE_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_WRONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_RDONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_WRITE:
            os_perm = O_RDWR;
            break;
        default:
            return OS_ERROR;
    }

    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_CREAT;
    }
    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_TRUNC;
    }

    os_perm |= OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS;

    os_mode = S_IRUSR | S_IWUSR | S_IRGRP | S_IWGRP | S_IROTH | S_IWOTH;

    impl->fd = open(local_path, os_perm, os_mode);

    if (impl->fd < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("open(%s): %s\n", local_path, strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    /*
     * If the flags included O_NONBLOCK, then
     * enable the "select" call on this handle.
     */
    impl->selectable = ((os_perm & O_NONBLOCK) != 0);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in this function appear to modify any function parameter itself (which would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8). Evidence:
- Parameters: const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *local_path, int32 flags, int32 access_mode.
- There are no assignments to token or local_path (no statements like token = ... or local_path = ...). The only use of token is dereferencing (*token) when passed into the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro; that reads the value and does not modify the pointer parameter itself. Dereferencing to read the token value is permitted; modifying the object addressed by a pointer parameter is allowed by the rule (though here the pointee is const, so modification would violate const-correctness but no such modification occurs).
- The integral parameters flags and access_mode are only read (used in switch and bit tests); they are not reassigned.
- The code modifies impl->fd and impl->selectable, which are fields of an internal record obtained via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — these are not function parameters, so they are outside the scope of Rule 17.8.
- Calls such as open(local_path, ...) pass the pointer as an argument but do not modify the function parameter itself.
Given these points, there are no fragments that need investigation for Rule 17.8 in the provided function. If you want, you can inspect the definition of the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro to confirm it does not perform any unexpected modifications, but based on its usage here (*token) it is being used only for reading an index/value and not altering the parameter pointer.
